turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi there, it's Doctor Smith from Babylon.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi. Can you confirm you name, date of birth and your home address, please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, Sandra Bullock, uh, twentieth of February, nineteen fifty eight.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hello. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And your home address?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, seven three four, <UNIN/> court in St. <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, that's fine. Uh, are you in a private place that you can have a consultation at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I am.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, what can I do for you today?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, well, like five days ago I started having problems like a cough, and my nose is just constantly streaming.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, and are you normally fit and well?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, normally I'm diabetic, but other than that, like, generally pretty good.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, OK. So, just tell me about the last, did you say five days?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, five days or so ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. How about your cough at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, it's quite bad. It's kind of quite dry, um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I'm coughing maybe every twenty, thirty minutes or so.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, you bringing up any phlegm at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No. Any chest pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Chest what, sorry?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any pain in your chest?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any difficulty breathing, feeling short of breath or any pain when you take a deep breath?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, that's all fine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you coughed up any blood or anything like that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And what about your nose symptoms?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> front of your sinuses or anything?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, just <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, nothing up in here but just constant streaming, like, using a million tissues.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And any blood coming from the nose?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, it's pretty green.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, OK. Any other symptoms, like sore ears? Sore throat?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I <UNIN/> I've been feeling really hot, um, I don't know if it's fever as such, but, <UNIN/> like, to touch I'm quite hot but sometimes I'm feeling really chilly, needing to be under a blanket, that sort of thing.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you checked your temperature with a thermometer?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uhh, no, I haven't.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, and are you eating and drinking normally?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uhh, yes. Um, kind of around when it started, I had some diarrhoea, but I don't know if that was associated. But since then it's all been pretty fine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, you're drinking well, holding down fluids OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And passing water OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, that's fine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No <UNSURE>vomiting</UNSURE>, diarrhoea now?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, that's fine. Um, any rashes that you've noticed?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Rashes? Uhh, no, nothing like that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any headaches or change in your vision?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, um, I've had quite achy muscles, but that's pretty much it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And normally, do you have any chest problems?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you ever get wheezing, short of breath?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I mean, like, if I do intense exercise, then yes. But not <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/>. And, do you regularly have any infections in your chest, or anything that needs treatment, normally?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, uh, I've got hypertension, um, so I'm on some drugs for that, um, but that's it, really.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, any other medical problems?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, just the hypertension and the diabetes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and what type of drugs are you on?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I think something called metformin, and lisinopril I think is the other one.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and when did you last have your blood pressure checked?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, ooh, uh, <UNIN/> a while ago. Um, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> Do you know if it, do you know if it's been stable?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I can't remember.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And with your blood, with your diabetes, have you had a blood test recently?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yeah. Like.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, it was normal. It was around three weeks ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and do you know what dose of the lisinopril you're taking?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, two hundred.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Have you been able to pass water normally? Any increase in <UNIN/> in frequency that you're passing water or any increased thirst?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no, not particularly.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And has your weight been stable?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What is your weight and height?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, my height is five foot five, and my weight is sixty five kilograms.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And do you smoke at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You drink any alcohol?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, the odd cherry.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.Um, who do you live with at home?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, my partner and my dog.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And do you work?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yes. I'm an office manager.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And have you been doing anything yourself to help with the symptoms? Anything that you've bought in the chemist?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, uh, a quite a few lemon sips. Um, they seems to be helping.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you, what, what do you mean by quite a few? How many in, in a day do you normally take?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, maybe two or three. Maybe, like, at the start of the day and at the end of the day.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Have you noticed any improvement in that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. It tends to soothe my throat a bit for when I'm going to sleep.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, do you have any allergies to anything?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I sometimes suffer from some, like, hay fever. But, um, but it's not bad <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>. Any allergies to any medications at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not that I'm aware of, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, what you've described to me, it sounds like you, you probably have got an infection in the chest, um, because it's, it, you know, you're obviously getting symptoms of from your nose and your chest. Um, it sounds like you might have a high temperature, it's definitely worth getting a thermometer and checking your temperature.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. I can just get one of those at a pharmacy or something?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, and most of the time, these infections are caused by viruses, so they do normally settle by themselves. But it can take, you know, a week or two, um, and you can <UNIN/> persistently have the cough ongoing longer than that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, the important thing to do would be to take your temperature.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and if you feel like, if the temperature's ongoing, above thirty seven point five, thirty eight, um, and you keep spiking temperatures and that's not settling down, or your cough's getting worse, you're coughing up lots of nasty phlegm or you cough up any blood or get blood coming out your nose,

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: um, or any shortness of breath, chest pain, then we certainly would need to speak to you again. With the diabetes you are a bit more likely to get a bacterial infection than if you didn't have the diabetes, so it's something we do need to be careful of.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. So, then we would at potentially antibiotics at that time, perhaps?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, potentially. If it is, if it's not settling or the temperature's ongoing, getting worse, then we definitely need to talk to you again.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, have you got any other questions?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, no, that's all fine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: It's fine to carry on what you're doing at the moment, with the lemsip. I wouldn't take, and that, that contains paracetamol so don't take any other paracetamol containing products, um, with that at the same time.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, the cough syrup isn't advisable in the daytime because it's best for your body if you just keep coughing. But if you're kept up all night and you can't sleep at all, then it, it's OK to have a little bit of cough syrup, just to settle that down.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. Cool.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK? Do you have blood sugar checking equipment? Do you check? No, OK. Well, if you make sure that you have the regular diabetes and blood pressure checkups that your GP has asked you for?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I'm not at home.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, great. Alright then, take care. Bye.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Alright. Thanks so much. Bye.
